children.subject: apparently 61a, 61b, and 70 are good indicators of how students will do in upper division classes. 61c isn't as good an indicator from what i have heard, and 61a alone doesn't take into account some factors that determine one's ability to succeed in the field (working on big projects , math, etc.). And, for 61a and 61b the 3.3 isn't arbitrary because the bins for those classes are set at the start of the semester, so technically everyone could get an A+. but, statistically, students tend to perform about the same from semester to semester, and so with the current rigor of the curriculum a 3.3 allows a manageable number of students into the major.

history.content:
Hey! Had a family member ask me about why there is a GPA cap and I couldn't really give a solid answer. I mean, it's pretty obvious the cap is to limit the number of students that take CS upper divs bc Berkeley doesn't have the re$ource$ to accommodate that many students. 

But is there like an official statement from faculty/admin that was ever released around why GPA was chosen as the limiter and why it was set to 3.3 and why those specific classes were chosen? Can't seem to find anything on the piazza or website :/.

Also if you think about it for long enough, it does start to feel a little arbitrary for 3.3 bc the profs in the lower divs pretty much have complete control over how many students get B+ in the classes (based on how hard the tests are, extra points here an there, etc etc). Also why 61a/b and 70? Why not just 61a, why not also 61c?

Thanks all!
